## The argument

. . .

<br>

[Public demonstrations]{style="color:red;"} of **gender-based violence's** ***rejection*** should increase [reporting of gender crimes]{style="color:red;"} through three distinct **mechanisms**:

1. Increased [*empowerment*]{style="color:blue;"}

2. Increased [*in-group identification*]{style="color:blue;"}

3. [*Social norm*]{style="color:blue;"} change

<br>



![](person_question.png){fig-align="center"}

---

> "Limiting the age to 56 years excludes the oldest segments of the population that could potentially be the most conservative." (Gaggini)

. . .

> "Can 2019-2020 still not be the result of a backlash caused by feminist mobilisations? It can be considered plausible to assume that normalisation take  longer to settle than backlash." (Gaggini)

. . .

> "Why does sexism result in a vote for far-right parties? Or rather, is there no reverse causality?" (Gaggini)

---

> "It is evident that there is an American influence on the idea of the research question, as trying to prove the reality of the USA on Spanish ground." (Papathanasopoulou)

. . .

<br>

> "[...] it would be interesting to study the role of sexism in a country with an established radical right [...] Take Switzerland, for example, with the SVP party, [...] do feminist mobilisations activate the same mechanism highlighted by Anduiza and Rico?" (Gaggini)

---

> "One might even see the association between sexism and empowerment of the far right as a fluke, a random constellation of conditions and facts" (Papathanasopoulou)

. . .

<br>

> "I have also not been entirely convinced by the explanation of what modern sexism is, feeling that it is still hostile sexism but hidden and appearing as it should in the politically correct context." (Papathanasopoulou)
